captions.text:
- Many of us are familiar
 with the legend of Robin Hood.

But, for those of
  you who haven't been

watching Dr. Who this season,
 here's a brief primer.

He and his band of Merry
   Men, including Friar Tuck

and Little John lived
 in Sherwood Forest,

where they'd rob from
 the rich, and give
what they stole to the poor.

No one ever talks about
   their operating expenses,
which is weird to me.

Anyway, a lot of the
rich people in the area,

most notably Prince John, were
 decidedly not cool with this,

so they enlisted the help
   of the local constabulary

to stop Robin Hood,
  or at least cramp

his magnificent singing,
 dancing, linclon green style.

Today on TableTop, Ashley
   Clements, Derrick Mio
and Meredith Salenger are here

to join me on the outskirts
  of Sherwood Forest,

where we will find
   out who among us

can help Robin Hood by
smuggling in the most contraband

while also enriching
 ourselves as the most

crafty and corrupt
 Sheriff of Nottingham.
(upbeat music)

Sheriff of Nottingham
 is a bluffing game

designed by Brian Pope,
 Sergio Halaban and Andre Zatz.

In Nottingham, we
   play the perfectly

legitimate entrepreneurs
trying to sell

our totally ordinary goods to
 the fine people of the region.

We would never even consider
  smuggling contraband

into the city to fuel the
  rebellion led by Robin Hood.

That notion good sir,
 and or madam, as your

individual gender applies,
   is just preposterous.
Preposterous, I say!

Unfortunately, the
   sheriff is on the lookout,

and he has set up his
   office at a border check,

controlling what comes
in and out of the city.

But, luckily for us, the
sheriff's moral compass

now only points to his
   ever-fattening coin purse.

Bribing the sheriff
  is not only allowed,

but it is completely
 encouraged, and it is

the role-playing of this
shakedown in the game

that makes Sheriff of
 Nottingham so awesome.

Every turn, the
   sheriff announces

that Nottingham is
   open for business,

and he will be inspecting
   cargo coming into town.

The sheriff's
 position is indicated

by this bloated, pompous
 piece of cardboard right here.

Now, the players will
   load their merchant cart,

represented by
  these colorful bags.

Each player must
 declare how many goods

they are bringing into town,
  and of what single type.

As an example, I have got
 these three wedges of cheese,
I'd like to sell them in town.

I certainly don't know where
  this crossbow came from,

or how it wound
   up in my shipment.

Now, we all know that
   this crossbow is illegal,

because it's marked in
 red, and I certainly

should not try to
   sell it in town,

but it's worth as much as
   all of my cheese combined.

So, I'm going to
  declare four cheese,

and try to smuggle this
 crossbow past the checkpoint.

All the merchants now place
their goods into their sleeves,

and they pass their bags
over for inspection.

Now look, I know the
  sheriff is very busy
and has a taste for luxury.

So, I have included
this uh, application fee

of five dollars to speed
 along the inspection process.

This is very easy
  money to the sheriff

if he just looks the
  other way instead of

inspecting the bag
 for undeclared goods.

What do you mean,
   this is a bribe?

This is a donation to the
 sheriff's reelection campaign!

And we all know that
 campaign contributions
are protected free speech

in the United States
  of Nottingham.
Thank you, Supreme Court.

The players will try to
   use deception and bribery

to get their illegal goods
 across the border checkpoint,

and the sheriff will use
   intimidation and extortion
to get money out of the players.

Bribery versus
  extortion, awesome!

Who will get thrown into
the stocks for smuggling

and who can convince
the sheriff these aren't

the maladroits
  they're looking for,

return to their
business and move along?

Let's find out in
 Sheriff of Nottingham.

- I'm Ashley Clements
 and I'm an actress

best-known for starring in
   the Lizzie Bennet Diaries.

- My name is Derrick
 Mio, and I'm an actor.

Fans of Geek & Sundry
 will recognize me

as playing Elliot on the
   original series, Spooked.

- My name is Meredith
  Salenger and I'm an actress.

I have been on TableTop
before, playing

Quirkle and 12 Days,
  and I totally won

and it was amazing, I
 had the best day ever.
- This is Sheriff of Nottingham.

Normally the way you
 decide who goes first

in Sheriff of Nottingham
is by finding out

who has the most
 money on their person,

which I actually
  find kind of gross.

So instead of doing
  that, we have these

really cool dice, they're
 like, see who goes first dice.

They are mathematically
distributed so that

they cannot tie, and
 they're 12-sided dice
and they're awesome.
So I guess we'll just roll them,

and whoever has the
high roll will go first.

I rolled a seven,

Ashley rolled a 44 and
Derrick rolled a three.

title: Sheriff of Nottingham: Ashley Clements, Derek Mio & Meredith Salenger on TableTop S03E07

comments.text:
Some of that seems to have gotten messed up. Not sure how that happened. 
I'm sure you got what I tried to say.﻿
comments.author: richard robinson

comments.text:
Great game. This was cool. I want to see Star Trek:Zombies. Can't you just 
hear Picard saying,"Brains. Make it so." It would be classic. Have a great 
day.﻿
comments.author: richard robinson

comments.text: this game looks fun as hell﻿
comments.author: Havicc Brine

comments.text: Pls do conan the barbarian board game ﻿
comments.author: Ethan Allen

comments.text: Please do Werewolf﻿
comments.author: XinBiDe

comments.text:
This game seems attractive to me because the rules are simple. It is a 
little like poker.
I don't like it when the rules are too complicated, when there is a lot of 
reading required, or when you need to keep all the labyrinthine rules in 
your head so you can make strategic moves.
That said, I would probably just as soon play poker.﻿
comments.author: NoExitLoveNow

comments.text:
I thought this was a Dice Essentials pushed game to just cash in on the 
previous published version under "another name". Tabletop did a great job 
though of debunking that idea showing that it has been re-thought and 
works. Bought this game because of tabletop and we love playing it. Well 
done.  :)﻿
comments.author: GQ daddy

comments.text: "A chicken....a chicken..... wwwwHAAATTTTT?!?!"﻿
comments.author: SoShiBias

comments.text: Three of the scores were added wrong.﻿
comments.author: Mark Luhn

comments.text: this was a great game to watch :)﻿
comments.author: chaintm

comments.text: Damn Derek, they played you harder than a Mississippi pimp, lol!﻿
comments.author: Mike Jones

comments.text:
I love american pronunciations of Cities from outside the US... They always 
get it wrong :P eg. Not NottingHAM, but Notting'm﻿
comments.author: Shnigda

comments.text: Not abribe. An inducement.  :-)﻿
comments.author: Urhixidur

comments.text:
So Mr. Wheaton....I gather you are writing glowing articles praising the 
narrow ideologue Anita Sarkesian. If so please confirm so I can quit 
watching your videos. Thank you for your time. (never get an answer 
anyway).﻿
comments.author: bbbushhh

comments.text: I knew the person who didnt smuggle would win. ﻿
comments.author: Greg 1

comments.text:
Thanks Tabletop! Just bought this game and it's loads of fun. Thanks for 
all you do.﻿
comments.author: Mason D Monasterio

comments.text:
The rules of the older version were way better than this one. In this new 
version you give so much information that the uncertainty of bluffing is 
almost vanished from the game.﻿
comments.author: Oz Iazdi

comments.text:
This video rubs me the wrong way. I feel that Wil is rude and overbearing 
as a player in this video. It's not very kid friendly. Is he getting too 
much into character? What do you think?﻿
comments.author: byam79

comments.text: why dont they say that they ''have'' contreband but in reality they dont﻿
comments.author: Anne Piché

comments.author: Mosin P. Esquire

comments.text:
This just reinforces my belief that this is a bad bluffing game, because 
the only consistent way to win is to be honest.  If someone offers you a 
bribe you have no reason to take it, you are better off depriving them of 
the points than you will ever be from taking the money. And if nobody ever 
offers a bribe you have to check occasionally anyway to keep them honest, 
and then the Sheriff loses and the honest merchant wins that exchange.﻿

comments.author: Jukka-Pekka Tuominen

comments.text:
Always tell the truth. In the end you will always come out ahead. The 
expected return of lying is far less than the expected return of telling 
the truth.

According to the cards, the average value of a contraband was 5, so lets 
say five. Their is in fact, a 50% chance of being called out. So, you have 
a gain of 5 points on average. If you get let past, you gain roughly 10 
points in total (including what ever was in it). However, if you get called 
out, you gain only 5, but lose 5 coins, so you get nothing. (Even less 
money with more contraband). So on average, lying will give you 50%*0 + 
50%*10, or 5 coins.

Now lets take telling the truth. On average, a "legit hand" is roughly 6 
coins. If you aren't called out, you get 6 points. If you are called out, 
you get 6+6 coins. So 50%*6+50%*12=9 coins.

The expected return of always playing legit is higher than lying, 100% of 
the time. Conversely, if you always play legit, never call anyone out, and 
always accept the bribes. You will, still win. Let the other players call 
them out.

So if you want to win, play legit.

If you want to have fun, however, lie your ass off. Getting away with lying 
is always a better rush than getting called out while having a "legit 
hand".﻿

He's a fictional character, there is no "what he did".

But the "steal from the rich, give to the poor" stuck in the 1600s. There 
was no concept of retrieving illegitimate taxes in the oldest tales we 
still have - that's a more recent addition as well.
